awd_titl_txt: Preparing Preservice Mathematics Teachers for Success in High-Need Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, a team at Kansas State University (K-State), partnering with the Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation project, the Professional Development School Partnership, and the Center for Rural Education and Small Schools, will recruit and prepare mathematics majors for careers in teaching middle and high school mathematics. The project will (1) disburse scholarships for juniors, seniors, and post-baccalaureate mathematics majors to pursue careers in teaching; (2) provide opportunities for freshmen and sophomores to work in informal mathematics education settings both on and off campus; (3) implement a pre-service seminar and in-service mentoring program to support the Noyce Scholars in their first two years of teaching in high-need districts, with special emphasis on rural schools; and (4) conduct research into support structures appropriate to rural school mathematics placements. A focus on districts in southwest Kansas will also enable the project to build a larger base of Hispanic mathematics majors who are licensed to teach at the middle and high school level.

Project activities will include a year-long seminar focused on working with English-language learners in teaching mathematics, managing multiple mathematics teaching assignments, and integrating mathematics with other content areas. New teacher support will be provided through master teachers in each district assigned to mentor new teachers as well as an early teacher collaborative managed by the K-State College of Education Office of Innovation and Collaboration. Quantitative and qualitative methods will address questions such as: To what extent are the project's activities effective in increasing the number and diversity of mathematics majors with teacher licensure in middle and high school teaching? Which program components are most influential on scholars' career path choices and why? Findings will advance knowledge about preparing mathematics majors to teach in high-need rural school districts.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Preparing Preservice Mathematics Teachers for Success in High-Need Schools was an S&S Phase I program designed to increase the supply of highly qualified middle and high school teachers (Grades 6-12) in mathematics. The program aimed to provide opportunities for freshmen and sophomores to work in informal mathematics education settings both on and off campus, modify academic programs to enable Noyce Scholars to complete the existing Dual Major in four years, increase and diversify the number of undergraduate and graduate mathematics majors receiving licensure, develop a pre-service seminar and in-service mentoring program to support the Noyce Scholars in their first two years of teaching in high need districts, with special emphasis on rural schools, and strengthen relationships with high need districts throughout the state.

 

Overall, we recruited and graduated 21 undergraduate math majors and seven math graduates who received licensure. We provided several internship experiences ranging from working with KSU faculty to plan and run Family STEM nights at local school to assisting a middle school resource teacher to provide services in math and reading to recently migrated students. We surveyed scholars regarding their needs and collecting interview data from graduates by asking them to report on what they felt prepared for and what they felt unprepared for when they began teaching. From these data, we analyzed the significant themes that emerged for our scholars and this work was published at the Mathematics Teacher Education and Development journal. We also engaged in a case study of one particular scholar who was a first-year teacher in a rural school district. The purpose was to better understand how the math teaching practice of “support productive struggle” translates from a basic level of understanding as a preservice teacher to actual classroom practice as a first-year teacher.

 

Throughout the program, we provided topical seminars and professional development opportunities such as managing student behavior, classroom management, escalation cycle, laying the groundwork for a collaborative culture, and a novice teacher panel that included first and second year teachers. The Covid-19 pandemic was challenging for new teachers; in particular, it prevented some activities in school and to be able to see kids and their reactions. We shared our experience and discussed teaching strategies during the pandemic. Overall, we found that Scholars enjoyed the seminars and found them to be very productive.

 

We built on work done early in the program to streamline courses and enable scholars to complete the dual degree in four years. The Noyce program has provided an opportunity to build solid relationships between the Mathematics Department and the College of Education. In alignment with our goal of developing a pre-service seminar and in-service mentoring program to support the Noyce Scholars, we provided support and informal mentoring via emails, phone calls, face to face meetings, and using social media. Scholars reached out to the PI with concerns and she offered encouragement and support and provides resources and interventions.

 

Intellectual Merit

The work from our grant has provided us with substantial insights into the recruitment and retention process of highly qualified mathematics teachers, particularly for high needs schools and contexts. We have evidence that Noyce scholars found topical seminars to be particularly useful in expanding what they knew and what they needed to know before they began their career and that personal connections and relationships played a critical role in their success. Our interviews, research, and analyses resulted in a high-quality peer-reviewed journal publication that explored the themes that matter to Noyce scholars as well as the contributing factors to their recruitment and retention. Our case study project illuminated the “productive struggle” that many teachers experience as they translate their basic understanding of supporting student thinking to actual practice.

 

Broader Impacts

We streamlined the pathway for undergraduates to obtain a dual major in mathematics and education in four years. By providing the scholarship and resources to 21 undergraduate math majors and seven math graduate, we substantially increased the number of highly qualified mathematics teachers serving in high needs contexts. These scholars then went on to serve hundreds and thousands of students who need teachers with excellent math background. In particular, many of these schools are representative of the high needs and rural schools throughout the Great Plains and in Kansas specifically. We were also able to diversify the pool of scholars to reflect the diversity of the schools that we served.

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2023
Modified by: Sherri Martinie
